arguments.desc: If legitimate political authority rests on popular consent (premise 1), then mere force or conquest, which lacks free consent, cannot create legitimate government; therefore conquest does not alone establish rightful authority (conclusion 2).

Given that relative exchangeable value depends on the quantity of labour embodied in commodities (premise 5), any improvement that reduces required labour will lower that commodity's relative value (conclusion 6).

Because introspection is scientifically unreliable and must be checked by external observation (premise 4), psychology's scientific method should emphasize externally observable behaviour (conclusion 2).
Russell: since our immediate knowledge consists of sense-data (premise), we infer a hypothesis of enduring physical objects to explain recurrent and intersubjectively similar sense-data (conclusion).

Hume's claims that promise-obligation is a human invention (1) and that self-interest is the operative motive in promising (3) support the broader claim that justice and property are social artifices arising from conventions aligning self-interest (2).

If sensible qualities are mind-dependent (4) but intrinsic values require modal independence from subjective variation (6), then an account that grounds intrinsic values in those sensible qualities faces a coherence problem (8).

From the general Humean principle that factual inferences rest on experience (1) and the fragility of analogical inference when cases differ (2), conclude that extending inference to divine nature beyond experience is only presumptive (7).

Even accepting the observation that the world resembles a machine (3), the acknowledged weakness of analogy between dissimilar cases (2) implies the design-based inference to the deity's nature is uncertain (7).

Because reason operates by linking ideas and regulating assent (4), distinguishes necessary truths from contingent positive laws (5), and introspective sources are fallible/limited (6), beliefs that transcend experience—such as definitive claims about divine nature—remain only presumptive and uncertain (7).

Hume locates property in imaginative relations (occupation, prescription, accession) and Locke treats species/essences as mind-made nominal essences; together these support the general conclusion that social and classificatory institutions are mental/social constructions rather than fixed natural essences.

If lively ideas of others convert into our own impressions (sympathy) (1) and pride/humility require relations to self plus separate pleasure/uneasiness (2), then the observed similar bodily qualities and relations in animals imply they exhibit pride/humility by the same mechanisms (3).
If rights are acquired or lost instantly and admit no gradual change (premise 2), then property rights must be treated as indivisible—either possessed fully or not at all (conclusion 1).

Because laws of justice are artificial conventions created to control particular and variable natural motives (premise 3), civil government arises to make the observance and execution of justice the immediate interest of some agents (magistrates) (conclusion 4).

Leibniz: if some (even imperceptible) impression or inclination always determines choice (11) and clear recognition of the good determines the will (12), then the notion of an undetermined freedom of indifference (10) is untenable.

Leibniz: the impossibility of a perfect equipoise in choice (9), together with the claim that some impression or circumstance always determines choice (11), implies that freedom of indifference (10) is a chimera.

General principles of tax incidence (taxes on rent fall on landlords; taxes on luxuries fall on consumers) make it plausible that tithes — a fixed fraction of gross produce — operate like a tax on raw produce, raising corn prices and ultimately burdening consumers (Ricardian linkage).

If freedom of indifference (choice without determining reason) is impossible (10) and choices are always determined (even by imperceptible impressions or circumstances) (11), then a clear recognition of the good will determine the will — though this determination need not be metaphysical necessity (12).

Because human expectation and inference depend on habit or custom (16) and because minds form entrenched associations that produce variable sympathies and motives (14), stable artificial conventions (laws of justice) are required to regulate behavior and avoid disorder (3).

Hume's general claim that expectation from past to future is a habit (16), together with the account that custom produces facility and an inclination (30), explains how the mind unites similar past impressions into a more vivid idea and thus forms probabilities (17).

Locke's analysis that ideas are true in themselves but falsehood arises from misattributed existence (13), together with his account that custom associates unrelated ideas into habitual connexions (14), supports that certain persistent affections or disorders are relieved over time by disuse rather than by reason because repeated association hardens connections (15).

From Spinoza's claim that the mind perceives external bodies only through ideas of bodily modifications (22) and that falsity is a privation of knowledge (24), it follows that memory is an association of ideas arising from the order and association of those bodily modifications (25).

If real doubt comes from unclear ideas (8) and ideas are not false in themselves but only misattributed (13), then falsity is best characterised as a privation or lack of knowledge rather than a positive property (24).

Because expectation that the future resembles the past arises from habit (16) and custom produces facility and inclinations (30), the mind forms probabilistic judgments by combining similar past impressions into more vivid unified ideas, yielding imperfect belief (17).

If all ideas are copies of impressions (premise 79), then repeated impressions generate habit and association; from that habitual association the mind forms the expectation that the future will resemble the past (conclusion 16).

If language habits treat general names as fixed meanings (premises 44 and 75), this fosters the false belief in abstract, determinate ideas—accounting for the philosophical error that we form abstract general ideas by stripping particulars (conclusion 43).

Hume's account that belief about unobserved matters rests on custom/habit (16) and that we form only probabilistic beliefs by uniting similar impressions (17) supports the claim that laws of justice are artificial conventions created to regulate variable human motives (3).

Locke's claim that all simple ideas come from things acting on the mind (46) together with the idea of infinity as a capacity for endless addition rather than a determinate concept (20) explains why our complex ideas of substances are inadequate: we lack a positive, comprehensive idea of underlying essences (47).

If absolute metaphysical necessity would destroy moral responsibility (premise 19), then denying absolute necessity allows God's foreknowledge and providence to be compatible with human freedom (conclusion 29).

If God chooses the best among possible worlds and permits some moral evil to secure the overall best (premise 73), then actions are not governed by absolute metaphysical necessity but by fitness/principle-of-best, supporting the rejection of absolute necessity for free actions (conclusion 19).

Spinoza's account that memory arises from the order and association of bodily modifications (premise 25) supports Russell's law-like claim that an organism's present response to a stimulus often depends on its past history (mnemic causation) (conclusion 26).
Hume's claim that custom/habit produces facility and inclinations (premise 30) explains our inductive expectation that the future will resemble the past as arising from habit (conclusion 16).

Because expectation that the future resembles the past (16) and the formation of facility/inclination through custom (30) explain how repeated associations give rise to firm ideas, they together ground Hume's claim that observed regular union of motives and circumstances leads us to infer a form of necessity in human actions (36).

Ricardo's analysis that a tax on raw agricultural produce raises its domestic price and affects wages and profits (66) supports the earlier claim that a tax on produce operates like a tax on raw produce/tithes and is ultimately transferred to consumers rather than falling on landlords alone (6).

Because sense-data are the immediate objects of sensation (premise 82), we posit physical objects as theoretical causes to explain recurrent and similar sense-data across observers and times (conclusion 81).
Given that introspective self-knowledge is unreliable and must be checked by external observation (premise 62), scientific psychology should focus on externally observable behaviour (conclusion 60).

Given that all ideas are derived from impressions (79) and that the idea of necessary connexion stems from habit/custom (107), it follows that the idea of power or efficacy requires some impression and so cannot be an innate or wholly distinct mental content (106).

Because expectation that the future resembles the past arises from habit (16) and analogical reasoning is weak when compared cases are dissimilar (125), all inferences about unobserved matters of fact rely on past experience and are therefore probabilistic rather than demonstrative (112).

If sensible qualities require perception (74) and the immediate causes of our perceptions are spirits (including God) rather than inert matter (78), then the immediate objects of perception are ideas in minds (76).

Given that ideas are not false in themselves but become false only by wrongful reference (13), and that abstract general ideas are nominal essences formed by the mind (90), the belief that abstract general ideas correspond to determinate real essences is a chief source of philosophical error (43).

If sensible objects have no existence independent of perception (premise 74), then material/uncertain accounts do not explain the production of ideas; hence the immediate causes of perceptions must be spirits (conclusion 78).

If laws of justice are artificial conventions created to restrain partial, variable natural motives (premise 3), then civil government arises to make the observance and execution of justice the immediate interest of particular agents (conclusion 4).

If a lively idea of another's passion converts into our own impression (premise 145), then moral approbation, which depends on sympathy and perceived social usefulness/harm, is grounded in that sympathetic conversion (conclusion 104).

Given the distinction between eternal/necessary truths and positive/contingent laws (premise 128), an absolute metaphysical necessity that eliminates such distinctions would undermine moral responsibility; hence varieties of necessity are required to preserve moral responsibility (conclusion 19).

If a tax generally raises a commodity's market price by at least the tax amount (premise 122) and taxes that raise wages are borne by diminished profits rather than landlords (premise 66), then taxes on particular classes of goods (luxuries vs. necessaries/raw produce) will differ in incidence: luxuries fall on consumers, while taxes on raw produce or necessaries tend to be shifted in ways that ultimately affect prices and shares of income (conclusion 21).

Custom (habit) creates facility and repetition; vivid particular images intensify passions — together these produce stable regularities of motive and action, which Hume treats as the empirical basis from which we infer necessity (compatibilist necessity).

If desires arising from reason are proportionate (40) and reason directs us to prefer greater future goods over lesser present goods (41), then a person guided by reason will prefer the general protections of law and so be more free in a well-ordered State than in isolated independence (conclusion 73).

Reason operates by forming generalisations from observation (127) and observation-based generalisations supply our reasons for believing other people exist (83); hence mere inspection of one's own private perceptions alone does not suffice to justify belief in other minds (conclusion 50).

If all inferences about matters of fact must be founded on experience (124) and reason only links ideas where supported by appropriate grounds (127), then speculative inferences about divine nature that extend beyond experience remain merely presumptive and uncertain (130).

If words (especially names of complex substances and mixed modes) have unstable or empty signification (174) and loose application of words masks distinct simple ideas (178), then philosophical reflection that relies on such language tends to increase doubt and lead from common sense into scepticism and paradox (42).

If the immediate causes of our perceptions are spirits (including God) rather than inert matter (premise 78), then sensible objects depend on perceiving minds and hence do not exist independently of perception (conclusion 74).
If there are no innate ideas (65) and all ideas originate from sensation and reflection (84), then simple ideas are produced by things acting on the mind (conclusion 46).

Given that all ideas derive from impressions (79) and that notions of necessary connexion arise from repeated conjunctions/habit (107), inferences about unobserved matters of fact are founded on experience/custom (conclusion 124).

If ideas arise from sensation and reflection (84) and our measures of time are conventions based on apparent regular returns and memory (37), then time is distinct from motion and motion serves chiefly as a means of measuring duration (conclusion 38).

Moore's analysis that 'exists' has a simple sense (premise 39) supports the claim that introspective observation alone cannot by itself justify belief in other minds (conclusion 50): one must posit external sense-contents (a non‑perceptual sense of existence) to ground such inferences.

Spinoza's claim that human decisions and emotions are determined by the necessity of nature (premise 121) highlights the worry Leibniz raises that an absolute necessity would undermine moral responsibility, thus underscoring the importance of Leibniz's distinctions among kinds/degrees of necessity (conclusion 19).

Because analogical reasoning is weak when compared cases are dissimilar (premise 125), analogical inferences from human minds to a divine mind (the design argument) are correspondingly weakened (conclusion 142).

Given that (a) a tax on a commodity raises its market price at least by the tax amount (122) and (b) a bounty on production alters relative prices without increasing national real produce (137), it follows that a bounty on exportation tends to affect the value of money by encouraging export/import flows (138).

If proper intellectual liberty is the power to suspend particular desires and deliberate (57), and desires arising from reason are proportionate and cannot be excessive (40), then under reason we should prefer the greater future good over lesser present goods (41).

If the ordinary word 'exists' has a simple sense distinct from 'is perceived' (39) but Berkeley claims sensible objects have no existence independent of perception (74), then grounding intrinsic values in mind-dependent sensible qualities is problematic or incoherent (105).
If ideas are passive and lack active power (157), then their production cannot be explained by inert corporeal matter alone; therefore the immediate causes of perceptions must be active spirits (78).
Given that exchangeable value is founded on the quantity of labour embodied in commodities (55), any improvement that saves labour will reduce the relative exchangeable value of that commodity (56).

If observation and generalisation give us reasons to infer other persons' existence (83) and the ordinary sense of 'exists' is distinct from 'is perceived' (39), then it is reasonable to treat external objects' existence as having the same simple sense as our experiences (166).

If tacit consent (possession/enjoyment of government benefits) counts as a form of consent (premise 119), then political authority that rests on consent (conclusion 51) can legitimately be grounded either on explicit or tacit consent.

Because all inferences about matters of fact are founded on experience (124) and there is a conceptual distinction between eternal/necessary truths and contingent positive laws (128), asserting an absolute metaphysical necessity that makes all actions inevitable would undermine moral responsibility — supporting the claim that such absolute necessity cannot obtain (19).

Given that exchangeable value is founded on the labour embodied in commodities (55) and labour-saving improvements reduce required labour and thus reduce exchangeable value (56), we derive the distinction that 'value' (labour-based) differs from 'riches' (abundance of goods), i.e., statement 113.
If the ordinary sense of 'exists' is distinct from 'is perceived' (premise 39), then it is coherent to suppose that material things may exist unperceived in that same simple sense (conclusion 166).

Hume: because human actions exhibit a constant regular union with motives and circumstances (premise 36), causal inference about human acts (and more generally cause–effect) derives from experience/habit rather than demonstrative necessity (conclusion 162).

Given the general principle that a tax on a commodity raises its market price by at least the tax amount (premise 122), a tax on raw agricultural produce will raise its domestic price and thus be partially borne by consumers (conclusion 66).

If political authority derives from the consent of the people (premise 151), then a ruler who breaches the trust by failing to preserve the form of government and the public good forfeits his authority and may be resisted (conclusion 67).

From Spinoza's claim that God's essence necessitates his decrees (70), it follows that human actions and affects occur by necessity grounded in nature, supporting the claim that human decisions and emotions are determined by necessity (121).

If improvements in machinery/distribution lower prices and affect wages/profits (190) and foreign trade increases the mass and variety of commodities without immediately raising exchangeable value (189), then capital will flow domestically to equalize profits but not freely emigrate between countries (191).

Because moral approbation arises from sympathy and perceived usefulness (104), the perceived intention behind an action (its apparent effect on connected others) strongly affects our feelings of love, hatred, gratitude, or condemnation (136).

If observations justify generalisations only when we have observed appropriate antecedent–consequent instances (240), and if we must distinguish raw perceptions from perceptions‑of‑perceiving to avoid conflation (241), then forming observational generalisations about recurrent perceptual patterns gives good reason to infer other persons exist (conclusion 83).

Given that introspective observation alone cannot justify belief in other minds (50) but that observation can justify a generalisation when real instances of both antecedent and consequent have been observed (240), the best observational route to belief in other minds is via suitable external generalisations—supporting the claim that observation yields reasons to believe other people exist (83).

If nominal essences are human-made (150) and language habitually gives general names a fixed meaning that creates illusion (75), then the philosophical error that we form abstract determinate ideas by stripping particulars (43) is explained.

Given that knowledge-by-acquaintance is primary (239) and truth is a correspondence between belief and fact (156), self-evidence must admit degrees (155): acquaintance and correspondence explain gradations of epistemic certainty.

If abstract ideas with names determine species (44) and consistent use of the same word reduces confusion (194), then loose or shifting signification of words (174) is a chief source of philosophical disputation and error.

If sensible things cannot exist independently of perception (premise 74), then their continued existence requires a perceiver beyond finite minds, so positing an infinite perceiving mind (God) explains their continued existence (conclusion 163).

If the unstable or shifting signification of words causes philosophical error and wrangling (premise 174), then the linguistic habit of treating general names as single fixed meanings fosters the false belief in abstract, determinate general ideas (conclusion 43).

If people enter society primarily to obtain an impartial authority for appeals (223) and political authority properly originates from consent (151), then society is constituted by collectively relinquishing private rights and transferring judgment/punishment to the community (144).

Because individuals acquire property by labour (27) but seek protection from the state of war via a common authority (223), they have reason to give consent and form political power—supporting that government originates in human consent (151).

If reason is inert with respect to passions and cannot by itself produce actions (173) and a present impression vivifies related ideas producing belief/assent (119), then moral approbation naturally arises from immediate sympathetic pleasure plus reflective judgment about tendencies to promote happiness (220).

Hume's claim that property/possession depend on imaginative relations (148) together with Locke's account that genera/species and their essences are the work of the understanding via abstract ideas (224) jointly support the broader conclusion that institutions (property, promises, species-names, government) are human mental/social constructions (152).

If ideas and impressions share the same component parts and differ only in vivacity (114), and sympathy/relations can convert ideas into impressions (116), then a sufficiently lively idea can be converted into an impression producing real sensations (115).

Spinoza's claim that the order and connection of ideas is the same as the order and connection of things (161), together with the claim that the mind perceives external bodies only through ideas of bodily modifications (22), supports the conclusion that mind and body are one and the same thing conceived under different attributes (120).

If all ideas originate from impressions (79) and custom/habit produces facility and inclinations (30), then habitual association of past impressions yields our inductive expectation that the future will resemble the past (16).

Because ideas and impressions affect one another only when joined by relations (272) and a lively idea of another's passion can convert into our own impression (145), sympathy (the associative transition) grounds moral approbation based on fellow‑feeling and perceived usefulness (104).

Given Russell's claim that knowledge by acquaintance (sense‑data, memory, introspection) is epistemically primary (239), we must treat perceptions and perceptions‑of‑perceiving as distinct observable contents when inferring external objects (supports 241).

If moral distinctions spring from sentiment rather than reason (173) and sympathy vivifies others' passions into our own impressions (145), then moral approbation naturally derives from immediate sympathetic pleasure together with reflective judgment about tendencies (220).

Given mental continuity across species (59) and the fallibility of introspection that must be checked by external observation (62), psychology should prioritize externally observable behaviour as its scientific method (60).

If civil society is constituted by individuals transferring their private right to judge and punish to a common authority (144), then legislative authority must be fiduciary, promulgated by standing laws, and limited to the public good (170).

If causal laws are best expressed as local/differential laws (225) and sense‑data are the immediate objects of sensation (82), then treating physical objects as constructions (collections of correlated particulars) is justified (227).

If God selects the best among possibles (73) and there is a distinction between eternal/necessary truths and positive/contingent laws (128), then rejecting absolute metaphysical necessity preserves moral responsibility and allows compatibility of providence with freedom (19).

Given that introspective self‑knowledge is scientifically unreliable and must be checked by external observation (62), and that images and sensations differ in causal origin (228), it follows that introspection is fallible and not inherently more certain than perception (97).

If using the same word constantly in the same sense reduces confusion (245), then the lack of such consistent usage (unstable/empty signification of words) is a primary cause of disputation and error (174).

Since words immediately signify the speaker's ideas (274) and abstract/general names are formed by mental determinations (nominal essences) (90), the habit of treating general names as single determinate ideas explains the philosophical error that the mind forms abstract ideas by stripping particulars (43).

Russell: because self-evidence is gradational (155) and truth is correspondence (156), derivative beliefs that rest on immediate acquaintance are epistemically primary — supporting the claim that knowledge by acquaintance is logically primary (239).

Given gradational self-evidence (155) and the primacy of acquaintance (239), reason must operate by linking acquaintance-based premises to conclusions (i.e., derivative knowledge depends on intuitions and their connections), thus supporting Locke/Russell's claim about reason's role in linking truths (127).

If people enter society to secure an impartial authority (223) and three fundamental rules (stability of possession, consensual transfer, performance of promises) are prerequisites for stable society (258), then civil society is constituted by collectively relinquishing private punitive rights and creating common authorities (144).

Consent to unite into a people (151) and the desire for an impartial authority to decide disputes (223) together explain constitution of civil society as the transfer of private judgment/punishment to a public judge (144).

If the end of society is preservation of property and legislative power is founded to secure that end (134), and the legislature cannot take property without consent (138), then the legislature is a fiduciary, limited power obliged to the public good (170).

Given that natural laws reflect a chosen moral necessity (28) and that Spinoza treats God’s will as necessitated by his essence (54), we need Leibniz’s distinctions among kinds/degrees of necessity to preserve moral responsibility and avoid an absolute determinism that would destroy accountability (19).

If we have a strong propensity to believe some sensibles exist unexperienced (premise 175), this supports Moore's ordinary-sense distinction that 'exists' is a simple sense distinct from 'is perceived' (conclusion 166).

Reason forms generalisations from observation (127) and the ordinary word 'exists' has a simple sense (39); therefore mere introspective observation cannot by itself justify belief in other minds (50).

If reason works by linking truths and regulating assent (127), then theological mysteries that do not contradict those linked truths can legitimately be said to transcend but not oppose human reason (supports statement 218).

Given that nominal essences are abstract ideas annexed to names (150) and simple ideas derive from things acting on the mind (159), it follows that our species-classification depends on nominal essences rather than on unknowable real essences (215).

Because conquest cannot create legitimate government without the people's consent (52) and tacit consent requires actual enjoyment of protection/benefits (180), government imposed by force lacks the genuine, durable consent that makes one a full member of a commonwealth (315).
If human decisions are explained by natural necessity (121), then distinguishing kinds of necessity (metaphysical vs moral) (231) is needed to avoid destroying moral responsibility (19).

Because repeated past impressions increase the vivacity/probability of belief (303) and inferences about matters of fact are founded on experience (124), knowledge of unobserved facts depends on probabilistic inference from past experience (112).

If the mind's tendency to smooth transitions among successive perceptions causes us to posit continuous enduring substances (230), then intense philosophical reflection on these origins increases sceptical doubt about the senses (42).

If unguided matter plus selection of stable forms can account for apparent adaptation (268) and analogical reasoning is weak when compared cases are dissimilar (125), then analogical design inferences from human artifacts to a divine mind are weakened (142).

Locke's distinction of duration from motion (38) together with Berkeley's claim that finite extensions do not contain innumerable perceptible parts (188) supports the Humean/epistemic claim that our ideas of extension and duration resolve into a finite number of simple, indivisible parts (93).

Ricardo's account that rising food prices raise wages and squeeze profits (285), together with the fact that machinery/distribution improvements lower prices and affect wages/profits (190), together underwrite the tendency for the general rate of profit to fall as society advances (318).

Hume's claim that vivid particular images intensify passions (31) and Russell's law-like mnemic dependence of present responses on past history (26) together explain how the imagination can transform the idea of another's passion into a present impression in ourselves—i.e., sympathy (116).

Locke's claim that simple ideas are produced by things acting on the mind (46) together with Hume's principle that all ideas are derived from impressions (79) support the general Humean conclusion that inferences about matters of fact must be grounded in experience (124).

Because smooth transitions among interrupted resembling perceptions (230) and the imagination's tendency to mistake successive similar perceptions for continuity (192) produce a sense of unity, they explain Hume's conclusion that personal identity is a bundle or succession of perceptions rather than a simple substance (111).

Ricardo's point that part of 'rent' can reflect capital expended on buildings (331) combined with the general tax‑incidence rule that a tax raises a commodity's price by at least the tax (122) supports the claim that a tax on produce (or tithes) operates like a tax on raw produce and is ultimately borne by consumers (6).

Russell: because causal laws function as local, instantaneous laws of change (225) and 'causes' are better understood as nearly‑invariable antecedents rather than unique, metaphysically necessary ancestors (226), we should treat causal claims in physics as local laws of change (169).

Locke: unstable or shifting signification of words (174) combined with the remedy of using words consistently (245) supports the conclusion that philosophical inquiry requires precise ideas and stricter signification than ordinary discourse (283).

Berkeley/Hume linkage: if sensible qualities exist only in perception (74) and our ideas of extension/duration arise only via sensible perception (92), then the continued existence of sensible things requires a perceiving mind beyond finite perceivers — yielding the inference to an infinite perceiver (163).

If reason links truths (127) and distinguishes eternal necessary verities from positive contingent laws (128), then mysteries that transcend natural reason can nonetheless be compatible with faith without contradiction (supports 218).

Given Locke's claim that simple ideas are produced by things acting on the mind (46) and Berkeley's claim that ideas are passive and cannot be explained by inert matter (157), one is led to construe laws of nature as regular methods by which an active perceiving Spirit excites ideas (311).

If knowledge by acquaintance (direct awareness of sense-data) is epistemically primary (239) and sense-data are the immediate objects of sensation (82), then physical science must construct a public physical space (distinct from private sensory spaces) to relate and systematise those immediate data (351).

If God chooses the best among possibles (73) and moral necessity (choice by reason) differs from metaphysical necessity (231), then denying such distinctions would undermine freedom — thus distinctions among kinds/degrees of necessity are required to preserve moral responsibility (19).

Given that desire can be analysed as observable behaviour-cycles (235) and that psychoanalytic/empirical evidence reveals 'unconscious' desires via behaviour (236), unconscious desires are best interpreted as causal tendencies or dispositional behavioural laws rather than mysterious inner agents (187).

If words must have determinate ideas annexed (356) and consistent use of the same word in one sense reduces confusion (194), then the minimal remedy for lexical confusion is to use the same word consistently in the same sense when instructing or persuading others (245).

Russell's analysis (images distinct from sensations; desire as behaviour‑cycle) supports the behaviourist/dispositional reading that unconscious desires are best interpreted as causal tendencies or habit-systems rather than mysterious inner agents.

If simple substances are genuine agents of their inward actions (248) and God may pre-establish constitutions so bodies and monads correlate without physical influence (203), then denying activity to created substances would lead to pantheistic collapse; recognizing created substances as agents avoids that consequence (297).

Locke's account that nominal essences are human‑made abstract ideas (150) plus that general terms are produced by abstraction (224) explains how language and abstraction foster the false belief in determinate abstract essences—the chief philosophical source of error (43).

If general terms derive their generality from words standing for many particulars (326) and words are arbitrary sensible signs that immediately signify speakers' ideas (207), then the linguistic practice of general naming fosters the illusion that abstract, determinate ideas exist—accounting for the philosophical error about abstract general ideas (43).

Given that introspection is fallible and must be checked by external observation (97) and that images can be as vivid as sensations and thus deceive belief (384), scientific psychology should rely on externally observable behaviour rather than uncritically on introspective reports (60).

If eternal truths/moral principles depend on divine understanding (72) and there is a conceptual distinction between eternal/necessary truths and contingent positive laws (128), then God selecting the best among possibles and permitting certain evils as part of the best overall plan is coherent (supports 73).

If the legislative is a fiduciary, limited power that must govern by promulgated laws (170) and cannot take private property without consent (138), then legitimate political authority depends on the people's consent (51).

Because political authority originates from popular consent (151) and the legislative is a fiduciary power limited to the public good (170), a ruler who breaches that trust forfeits legitimate authority and may be resisted (67).

If God chooses the best among possibles (73) and we must distinguish eternal (geometrical) truths from positive laws chosen for fitness (128), then God's laws of nature are best understood as choices reflecting fitness or moral necessity (391).

If our idea of time comes from the succession of ideas (353) and we cannot know exact equality of two durations (37), then measuring time requires relying on repeatedly recurring, apparently equal periods (290).

Because sense-data are the immediate objects of sensation (82) and apparent properties vary with observer and conditions (388), it is reasonable to construe physical objects as constructions (collections of correlated appearances) that explain recurrent sense-data (227).

Hume: the world's order and apparent fitness resemble human-made contrivances (premise 126); yet analogical inferences are weak when compared cases are dissimilar (premise 125). Together these premises justify the characterization of the design argument as an analogical inference from observed order to an intelligent cause (conclusion 141), while also indicating its limited evidential force.

Moore: if the ordinary sense of 'exists' is distinct from 'is perceived' (premise 39) and observation yields generalisations that make the existence of other people the best explanation of recurrent perceptual patterns (premise 83), then positing other minds is empirically supported when that hypothesis systematically enables successful predictions of our future perceptions (conclusion 348).

If there is no single universal time but only local biographies (394) and a mind can be characterised as a perspective at a brain-place (415), then the best way to construe physical objects is as constructions: collections of correlated particulars across places (227).

The specious present includes retained immediate past (332) and a present impression vivifies related ideas producing belief (119); together these explain how imagination plus memory produce a belief in the continued existence of objects (395).

Images and sensations have distinct causal origins (228) and confidence in memory relies on a felt familiarity (383); from these facts it follows that introspection (relying on images/memory) is fallible and not inherently more certain than perception (97).

Resemblance among interrupted perceptions (192) and the vivacity relation between impressions and ideas (114) together explain why imagination and memory produce belief in the continued existence of external objects (395).

If an omnipotent God needs no inert instruments (360) and ideas are passive and cannot be efficient causes (157), then the immediate causes of perceptions must be active spirits (78) rather than inert matter.

Because inductive expectation arises from habit (16) and resemblance/smooth transition among interrupted perceptions confuses succession for identity (192), the mind tends to posit an enduring substance or continuous identity (230).

If words often have unstable or shifting signification (174) and language habitually treats general names as having fixed determinate meanings (75), then this linguistic behaviour fosters the mistaken belief that abstract, determinate general ideas exist (43).

Given that sense‑data are the immediate objects of sensation (82) and knowledge-by-acquaintance (sense‑data/memory) is epistemically primary (239), it is reasonable to construe physical objects as constructions (collections of correlated particulars) that explain those sense‑data (227).

If many true beliefs depend for their existence on prior human minds (246) and the same non‑verbal idea, whenever reproduced, would be true at any time (358), then causing a belief to exist is not the same as making it true; to make a belief true one must help produce the corresponding fact (262).

Ricardo: productivity increases abundance without raising exchangeable value (392) and value depends on labour embodied (55); therefore distinguish 'riches' (abundance) from exchangeable 'value' (113).

If bounties/subsidies divert capital and temporarily raise prices (137) and rent arises when cultivation extends to inferior land (140), then such policies can lead to cultivation of poorer land and hence to higher rent (364).

From (79) all ideas derive from impressions and (272) ideas influence one another only when joined by relations (resemblance/contiguity/causation), therefore repeated similar past impressions unite and increase vivacity, explaining why the strength of belief or probability grows with the number/vividness of past instances (303).

Given (328) the object of the idea constituting the human mind is the human body and (26) an organism's present responses often depend on its past history (mnemic causation), it follows that memory is an association of ideas arising from the bodily modifications (25).

If the natural (subsistence) price of labour depends on the price of food and necessaries (183), and an increase in capital raises demand for labour (185), then the general tendency as society progresses is for profits to fall unless countered — yielding the tendency described in 318.

Leibniz: the practical harm of the 'lazy reason' (355) together with the need to distinguish kinds of necessity (231) supports the claim that absolute metaphysical necessity would destroy moral responsibility (19).

From the design (analogy) argument (141) and the observation that expanding empirical knowledge increases dissimilarity from human artifacts (432), infer that analogical inferences to divine attributes are weakened (142).

If real doubt stems from unclear ideas (8) and words must be tied to determinate ideas (356), then philosophical reflection conducted with indeterminate language tends to increase doubt and sceptical paradox (42).

Given that unstable or shifting signification of words fuels disputation (174) and that using the same word consistently reduces confusion (356), one is led to the remedy of constant usage to reduce philosophical error (245).

If primary sensible qualities are in practice mind-dependent (463) and intrinsic value is intended to be independent of subjective variation (103), then grounding intrinsic values in mind-dependent sensible qualities creates an incoherence about intrinsic values (105).
If all ideas derive from impressions (79) and perception requires organic impressions reaching the brain (472), then simple ideas are produced by things acting on the mind (46).

If reason operates by linking truths (127) and mysteries may transcend but not contradict reason (218), then faith can be grounded by appropriate evidential grounds (external testimony and inward motion) even when mysteries are not fully comprehended (385).

Deep philosophical reflection that increases doubt (518), combined with a social tendency to prefer outward religious forms (354), makes scepticism about natural theology increase receptivity to revealed religion (434).

If words must have a determinate idea annexed (356) and consistent word‑use reduces confusion (245), then replacing vague locutions by determinately‑annexed terminology (e.g., 'determinate/determined') reduces conceptual confusion (494).

Given that desire is central to human essence (210) and pleasure/pain are transitions in perfection (337), emotions will involve both bodily changes and mental contents (i.e., complex processes of sensations, images, and movements) — matching Russell's analysis of emotions as complex processes (502).

If God freely compares all possibles and selects the best by weighing degrees of perfection (489), and if permitting some evils can be required to secure the best overall world (73), then God's roles of goodness, wisdom, and power are distinct and operate together (520).
